titleproper.value: Guide to the Americans for a Progressive Israel Records <num>TAM.147</num>

author.value: Collection processed by Katja Vehlow, 2001. Edited by Nicole Greenhouse for compliance with DACS and Tamiment Required Elements for Archival Description and to reflect the incorporation of nonprint materials, Sept 2013.

publisher.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

addressline: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive

creation.value: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace <date>2018-04-20T18:56:23</date>

corpname.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

unittitle.value: Americans for a Progressive Israel Records

extent.value: in one record carton and one manuscript box.

abstract.value: Americans for Progressive Israel was a socialist-Zionist support organization from 1947-1997. The collection contains correspondence, writings, conference materials, administrative materials, photographs, and their periodical, <emph render="italic">Israel Horizons</emph>.

p.value: Identification of item, date; Americans for a Progressive Israel Records; TAM 147; box number; folder number; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.

Materials found in repository; provenance is unknown but was likely a gift of the organization circa 1992. The accession numbers associated with this gift are 1992.018, 1992.019, NPA.2005.243, and NPA.2005.055.

Americans for Progressive Israel (API) was founded in 1947 to function as a less ideologically-based support organization by the Hashomer Hatzair, a socialist-Zionist organization. API was founded by Moshe Kagan. API's periodical, <emph render="italic">Israel Horizons</emph>, was created initially by the Progressive Zionist League in 1952. In 1997, API merged with Education Fund for Israeli Civil Rights and Peace and became Meretz USA. In 2011, Meretz changed its name to Partners for Progressive Israel. <emph render="italic">Israel Horizons</emph> ceased publication in 2011. API was active in international Zionist work, and conducted educational programs.

The collection focuses on events and issues in Israel, notably Israel's relations with the Arab world, and contains correspondence with other left-wing Israeli political parties, minutes, annual reports and other administrative material. There is also some correspondence and administrative material, including minutes and annual reports. The majority of the materials date from the 1980s. There is a significant amount of material related to its publication, <emph render="italic">Israel Horizons</emph>. The collection also holds color and black-and-white photographs from 1937 up to the 1980s. Images include photographs of Kibbutz Ein Hashofet and photographs of meetings from the 1980s from disassembled albums.

subject.value: Jews -- United States -- Attitudes toward Israel.
Arab-Israeli conflict |x Foreign public opinion, American.
